caption_original: Canada is home to 532 species who are at risk due to ecosystem degradation and loss. It is up to all Canadians to work together to help protect and conserve their habitat. Today, a newly formed advisory committee met with Minister McKenna to find practical solutions for these creatures. By working together, we can safeguard the health of our Canadian wildlife and ecosystems!

Today, a newly formed advisory committee met with Minister McKenna to find practical solutions for these creatures. By working together, we can safeguard the health of our Canadian wildlife and ecosystems!

Supporting clean freshwater is a priority for the Government of Canada. Protecting freshwater and marine ecosystems is vital to the health and well-being of current and future generations of Canadians.

And that’s why #Budget2017 provides up to $70.5 million for protecting Canada’s freshwater resources.

caption_original:
Attention weather buffs! If you‘re going to be in the #Gander, #NL area on May 7, you’ll want to drop by the Hurricane Awareness Tour and check out the hurricane hunter aircraft used by the US National Hurricane Center and the US Air Force. 

These specialized planes use cutting edge technology to gain valuable information on tropical storms which could impact the Atlantic coast of Canada and the US. You’ll get to tour the aircraft, meet American and Canadian hurricane meteorologists and check out the US National Hurricane Center’s Hurricane Awareness Tour exhibition. Save the date! ✈️ http://ow.ly/PBbK30bgRns

caption_original: The Government of Canada has ratified the Minamata Convention, a global legally binding treaty to protect human health and the environment from the adverse effects of mercury. With this agreement Canada emphasizes its commitment to the protection of our Arctic environment and the health of all Canadians, in particular of our Indigenous peoples, who are being exposed to elevated levels of mercury through the consumption of their traditional foods. http://ow.ly/D03630aFngh

caption_original:
Today is National #LookUpAtTheSkyDay – a day to take some time to look up at the sky! 

Did you know that 3.1 megatonnes of pollutants were directly released to air in Canada in 2015? Most are from a group of pollutants known as Criteria Air Contaminants, responsible for smog and acid rain. They include pollutants like carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds and particulate matter. 

To learn more about these and other releases to the environment, check out the National Pollutant Release Inventory’s Summary Report: http://ow.ly/3YOs30aQcIP

Most are from a group of pollutants known as Criteria Air Contaminants, responsible for smog and acid rain. They include pollutants like carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds and particulate matter. To learn more about these and other releases to the environment, check out the National Pollutant Release Inventory’s Summary Report:

April 14 marked the Geological Survey of Canada 175th anniversary! To commemorate the Survey’s history and contribution, we will be featuring 175 objects that represent its ongoing commitment to the discovery, exploration and mapping of Canada and its resources. 

Follow along as we tell you the story of Canada’s past and present through the eyes of our nation’s oldest government organization. http://ow.ly/hi0y30b3RRr

caption_original: Did you know that the Cap Tourmente National Wildlife Area in Quebec is the only wildlife area in the country that offers controlled-hunting program for the Greater Snow Goose? This hunt helps to slow the growth of an overabundant goose population and ensures the sound management of the species. http://ow.ly/pQs730awJGH

Climate change is an economic opportunity for Canada. The world is undeniably moving towards cleaner technologies, ones that use renewable and sustainable sources of energy, emit less pollution and use fewer resources. 

When it comes to clean technology, Canada has the opportunity to be a true global leader—creating good jobs for Canadians while helping to meet our climate change goals. http://ow.ly/zfFO30aDDfN

Work on stage one of the #RandleReef project resumed this spring, which includes the construction of an Engineered Containment Facility (ECF).

The ECF will securely hold the most heavily contaminated sediment and is expected to be completed by Fall. #HamOnt Bay Area Restoration Council
